comments.raw_text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:5.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/5.0
Build ID: 20110615151330

Steps to reproduce:

I have imported mails from outlook (via outlook express).
The source code is for example:
From: <Müster, Max>


Actual results:

In message list the sender (from) will not be displayed.

Recipients (to) with umlauts will be displayed.


Expected results:

The sender shold be displayed as:
Müster, Max

comments.raw_text: Possibly the same underlying issue as bug 669925?
comments.text: Possibly the same underlying issue as bug 669925?

comments.raw_text:
(In reply to mtb from comment #0)
> The source code is for example:
> From: <Müster, Max>

Correct format is From: "Fist Last" <localpart@domainpart>, where localpart@domainpart is usualy one like username@gmail.com.
Is it data shown by View/Message Source of Tb?
If yes, what mail source is shown by MS Outlook Express?

comments.creator: m-wada@usa.com
comments.author: m-wada@usa.com
comments.raw_text:
(In reply to mtb from comment #5)
> Mail Source in MS Outlook Express is (the same):
> From: <Müster, Max>

Can you stil use MS Outlook who is original ower of the mail?
If yes, what From: header is sent by MS Outlook when you forward the mail as attachment?

> Message Source of Tb is:
> From: <Müster, Max>

When you execute "Reply" for the mail in Tb, what To: does Tb show?
I assume two To:'s, To: Müster and To: Max.

Tb looks to consider that first mail address in From: is Müster which is "localpart only mail address, mail address of no @domainpart part". So, as Jim Porter says, bug 669925 can occur on the mail.

Do you have contact, which is for mail address starts from "m" or "M" such as "Mike@a.b.c", in your address books? (Read bug 669925 comment #10)

Do you have contact, which is for mail address starts from "m" or "M" such as "Mike@a.b.c", in your address books? (Read bug 669925 comment #10)

comments.raw_text:
(In reply to mtb from comment #5)
> Message Source of Tb is:
> From: <Müster, Max>
(In reply to mtb from comment #0)
> Actual results:
> In message list the sender (from) will not be displayed.

I couldn't reproduce it with Tb 7. I see "<Müster, Max>"(no quote) in From column for crafted mail of "From: <Müster, Max>".
Can you reproduce your problem by next?
(1) Create a local mail folder(call Test)   
(2) Copy the imported mail to Test folder
    What string is shown at From column of thread pane?
(3) Folder Properties of Text, General, click "Repair Folder", then click OK.
    What string is shown at From column of thread pane?

comments.author: m-wada@usa.com
comments.creator: m-wada@usa.com

comments.text:
FYI.

When "<Müster, Max>"(no quote) was shown in From column of thread pane for the crafted mail, "from: Müster, Max [Star Mark, to add to address book]" was shown at message header pane.
And, if Star mark was clicked first time, addrbook entry with email="Müster, Max"(with quotes) was generated. If Star mark was clicked second time, the created entry was shown. Tb refused to save entry of emal="Müster, Max"(with quotes), when contact is edited.

Tb looks to consider that from addr is "Müster, Max"(without quotes).
When reply or composition, "Müster, Max"(without quotes) in To:, CC:. BCC:, is treated as two mail addresses without @domainpart which are separated by comma.
comments.raw_text:
FYI.

When "<Müster, Max>"(no quote) was shown in From column of thread pane for the crafted mail, "from: Müster, Max [Star Mark, to add to address book]" was shown at message header pane.
And, if Star mark was clicked first time, addrbook entry with email="Müster, Max"(with quotes) was generated. If Star mark was clicked second time, the created entry was shown. Tb refused to save entry of emal="Müster, Max"(with quotes), when contact is edited.

Tb looks to consider that from addr is "Müster, Max"(without quotes).
When reply or composition, "Müster, Max"(without quotes) in To:, CC:. BCC:, is treated as two mail addresses without @domainpart which are separated by comma.
